moves.1. e4 d6: I am black for this game. just wanted to post my solid opening on black. props if you can name it.
moves.2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3: white seems to be devoloping minors over pawn structure, which is common and there isn't a problem with it, but... well, you'll see.
moves.3... Bg4 4. Be2: the possible responses to this are this and h3. h3 leads to a fun noah's ark variation of the opening the end result of which is bh7, or I can take the night after h3, either way works. with the bishop its more of a build up situation.
moves.4... e6: now that I have my bishop out I don't want it coming back.
moves.5. O-O c6: a lot of opening is done at this point, especially because the c- bishop hasn't been able to move yet.
moves.6. d4 h6: I want the c-bishop to move, but I don't want to lose the knight, or get an unwanted pin.
moves.7. b4: trying to take down my c-pawn, are we?
moves.7... g5 8. d5: one of us finally takes the offensive. pins are all well and good, but iwas high time we started clearing part of the board.
moves.8... Bxf3 9. Bxf3 g4: though this pawn is relatively weak, it gets the job done.
moves.11. f3: well, I'm glad I don't have my white bishop anymore.
moves.13. Kh1 Qxb4 14. Bb2: ok, this is white's biggest mistake.
moves.17... Nc6: I missed it, I was rushing to play this game of blitz.
moves.18. Nc7+ Kd8 19. Nxa8 Nd4 20. Rfb1 Qa3 2: ok, I have now avenged the death of my rook.
moves.23. Rxf7: ?????? thanks for giving me the game.
moves.23... Qc1+ 24. Qf1 Qxf1#: the end of the game, his h3 ended up killing him.
